titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I was so much engaged this morning, that on going to the Treasury Office, with Catherine to hear Mr: Laurie, we found it too late on arriving there to go in, and returned home— We dined at Mr: Boyd’s, and returned home, early in the Evening— I wrote, as much as the time I had this day would allow; but was still left much in arrear.

2. We have been unable to collect a majority of the library Committee; but by obtaining the signature of Mr: T. M. Randolph have succeeded in procuring the amount of the Annual Appropriation, and an order upon Mr: Nourse for one third of the sum to Mr: Mitchill, Mr: Clay and myself severally— The Senate sat from 11 this morning untill 5. then adjourned untill 7. and sat again untill past 10 at Night— The Salt and Mediterranean fund Bill was brought from the House of Representatives, and pass’d to a second reading; which Mr: Turner moved should be done this day— Several members objected, and Mr: Turner gave notice that he should to-morrow offer a Resolution to suspend that part of the 12th: Rule, which forbids two readings on one day without unanimous consent— A bill for settling the accounts of William Eaton pass’d to the third reading; opposed by Mr: Giles, Mr: Sumter, and myself, and supported by Mr: Bayard, Mr: Clay and Mr: Bradley— It was a transaction which I so strongly disapproved that I had resolved to expose the nature of the claims which are thus to be pass’d; but Mr: Giles this day after the question was taken told me the business was settled out of doors— A great number of other bills were acted upon this day; but none which occasioned any debate— I dined with the Gentlemen who lodge at Mr: Coyl’s, and did not reach home untill near Midnight— I made some few preparations for my departure; but was so much fatigued and harrassed in body and mind, that I left them almost all undone.

3. The Salt and Mediterranean fund Bill employed the greatest part of this day— After being debated at the second, and passing to the third reading, Mr: Turner moved that it should be read the third time this day—to which I objected— He then brought forward his Resolution to suspend part of the 12th: Rule, which after long debate and various modifications was carried The bill was then read a third time and pass’d— The Bill to settle Eaton’s accounts also pass’d 16 to 12. The Senate sat untill pass’d 5 P.M—. Then adjourn’d to 7. and sat again untill almost Midnight— About 10. O’Clock the joint Committee of the two Houses, Dr: Mitchill and myself from the Senate, Mr: Varnum, Mr: Alston and Mr: Gregg from the House were sent with the usual notification of the recess to the President— He was not as usual at the closing of the Sessions, in the Committee room at the Capitol, being detained by indisposition at his own house— The joint Committee, excepting Mr: Gregg, went in a Carriage together, and carried eight or ten bills for his signature— After he had done this, he said he had expected to receive this Evening the Treaty, lately signed by our Ministers with the Commissioners of Great-Britain, at London; but it had not arrived— He had however seen a Copy received this afternoon by Mr: Erskine, which he had been so obliging as to lend him— Mr: Mitchill said we had been requested by several members of the Senate, who had heard of this copy received by Mr: Erskine, to enquire whether there would probably be a call of the Senate, at an early day, to consider the Treaty; as some of them would in that case prefer to remain here— The President replied in emphatic tone: “certainly not”— He then added that there were two things either of which would prevent him from troubling the Senate with the consideration of this Treaty— The one was that it contained no satisfactory Article respecting the impressment of men from our ships—not even what they had offered, at a previous stage of the Negotiation; and the other was a declaration delivered by the British Commissioners at the time when the Treaty was signed, purporting that the King reserved the right of retaliating, against the decree of the French Emperor of 21. November last; unless the United States should resist it— This the President said would involve us in the War, and compel us to make a common Cause with Great-Britain; and the only way he could account for our Ministers having signed such a Treaty, with such Circumstances, was by supposing that in the first panic of the french imperial decree they had concluded a war would be inevitable, and that we must make a common Cause with England. He should however continue amicable negotiation with England, and continue the suspension of the non-importation act— And instructions had been sent in January to our Ministers, which he supposed they had by this time received, to give notice, even if they should have signed the Treaty without the Article to protect our Seamen from impressment, that it would not be ratified, and to renew the Negotiation— The Members of the Committee returned to the Capitol; but I walk’d home which I reached not much before Midnight— The young Ladies soon after came in from a party at Mrs: Erskine’s.

4. I had engaged to go this morning in Company with Mr: Bradley; Coll: Read, and two or three other Members, by the way of Annapolis— We were to start about 5 O’Clock this morning, and Bradley was to engage the Carriage— I was up untill 3 this morning; packing my trunks, and getting ready to go— Then went to bed for about 2 hours and before 5. was up, and ready for the Stage— I breakfasted, and waited for the Carriage untill almost 8. when I sent Ned, and afterwards went myself to the Union Tavern and Stage-Office at George-town; where I found that our places had been taken in the Annapolis Stage; and that not having arrived, owing to the badness of the Roads, we could not go out this morning— To prevent a second disappointment, I engaged a seat in the Stage for Baltimore to-morrow morning— In the forenoon Mr: Tracy and Mr: Pitken called upon us.— They informed me that Mr: Bradley was gone to Baltimore, alone in a Chair— They also mentioned that Mr: Baldwin the Senator from Georgia died this morning.— I went to the Register of the Treasury, Mr: Nourse and received from him a check on the Branch Bank at Boston, for account of the library of Congress. After dinner I went, with all the family, excepting Mrs: Hellen to Mr: Boyd’s, where his child, born the 17th: of November last, was baptized by Mr: Balch, and named John Quincy Adams— The child was held by Eliza Johnson for my wife, and answered for by its father and myself— We spent the Evening there, but I came home early, being much fatigued, with the labours of a closing Session, and my late overwatchings— Having also to depart early to-morrow morning.

5. At 6 O’Clock this morning the Stage for Baltimore call’d and took me at Mr: Hellen’s—call’d first at Stelle’s, and next at Frost’s; where we took up Mr: Plumer, Mr: Ely, Mr: Hastings, and Mr: Nelson of Newbury-Port— With two other passengers— We found the roads very bad; and it snow’d the greatest part of the day; but cleared away towards Night— We breakfasted at Ross’s, and dined at Spurrier’s, where we found Mr: Quincy and his family— He left Washington yesterday morning, with his own Carriage and horses; and had been unable to get further than to Spurrier’s, in two days— We arrived at Evans’s tavern in Baltimore, about 9 O’Clock this Evening.

6. I was very unwell the whole Night, and entirely broken of my rest— At 9. this morning I embarked in the new line Packet George Washington Captain Owens— On going on board I met Mr: John Murray junr: of New-York, who has lately been married here, and who had accompanied to the vessel this Morning his brother in Law, a young Mr: Rogers, a student at Cambridge, returning there after the vacation— Mr: Hastings and Mr: Ely were the only members who embarked with us; the other members preferring to go on by Land— We had the weather almost entirely calm the whole day and Night— I continued quite unwell through the day, but found myself much better towards Evening.

7. At Sunrise this morning we landed at Court-House-Point, and immediately proceeded in two Stages to Newcastle— We took a cold breakfast at the half-way house; and on arriving at Newcastle, about noon we immediately embarked in the Packet Telegraph Captain Weldon for Philadelphia— The roads were as bad as those between Washington & Baltimore— On board the vessel we had the tide against us, and the wind though fair, very light— We reached Philadelphia, about 4. O’Clock at Night— And went to the City Hotel—Pierson’s, where we found many other members of Congress— Among the rest Genl: Wadsworth, who came in the packet of the Old-line, and arrived a few minutes after us.— There were also many of the New-York members, who had arrived here in the land-stages—

8. Several of our fellow-travellers proceeded on their journey this morning; but it being Sunday, and having some business to transact I determined to stay untill to-morrow— I called at Mr: Meredith’s; but did not find him at home— At Mr: Hopkinson’s, Mr: Ewing’s and Mr: Dennie’s; all of whom I found— I dined at Mr: Hopkinson’s, with Ewing— Mr: Dennie and Dr: Chapman came in after dinner, and we sat in conversation there untill between 9 and 10 at Night—

9. I had several times determined, on traveling this Road to take the road by the way of Burlington and Amboy; but had always before been prevented— The roads which I have usually travell’d are now so bad, that I was glad of an opportunity to go part of the way by water— I therefore took passage in the boat for Burlington, and left the wharf at Philadelphia, about ten O’Clock this morning— We had however a perfect calm the whole day; and although the distance is only twenty miles we were untill nearly 5 in the Afternoon before we came within a mile and a half of that place— The tide then making against us we were obliged to come to anchor, and landed in the skiff— We then walk’d the remainder of the way, and arrived at the Tavern, (Hutchings’s) just about Sun-set— Mr: Hastings, and young Mr: Rogers were the only two of our fellow-travellers from Baltimore who accompanied me; but on board the boat we found Mr: Watts of Philadelphia, and in him an agreeable traveling Companion— Mr: Hastings landed from the boat some time after us, and the Night so immediately came on that we could proceed no farther untill the morning.

10. We were dispatched from Burlington this morning not so early as we had expected— The roads are not so much frequented as those of the Mail Stages, and the policy at the Inns is rather to detain than to speed the traveller— We breakfasted, at a half-way house, about nine O’Clock, and dined at Crossweeks a Stage only fifteen Miles from Burlington— After dinner we came another Stage of the same distance, and arrived at Cranbury just before dark— The roads are as bad as I have ever known them; and thirty miles we found an entire and industrious day’s travel.

11. They kept us again this morning at Cranbury untill after eight O’Clock— We had twenty miles to ride, to South Amboy; where we arrived about one O’Clock P.M— It is at the mouth of the river Rariton; and there is only one house there— When we arrived the Packet from New-York had not got in; and our prospect was of having to wait untill to-morrow morning— Mr: Hastings made some enquiries respecting the prospect of our going away this Evening, of the Inn-holder, and was answered by him with so much rudeness and insolence that I determined not to pass the night at his house— The other gentlemen came to the same determination. We cross’d the ferry to Perth Amboy, which is a considerable settlement— We dined at a Tavern there, and engaged the skipper of an open boat for five dollars to take us this Night to Elizabeth-town Point— He transferr’d us, for half the money to an Oyster-boat, whose boat-man we finally bargained with for a dollar more, to take us to New-York— We went on board just before Sunset with a brisk breeze, which very soon died away and left us in a flat calm— About eleven O’Clock at Night we came to Anchor at Bergen-Point, and went on Shore— We found there a small tavern, and a couple of beds into which we stowed ourselves for the remainder of the Night—

12. About Sun-rise this morning, our boatman, whose own hovel was half a mile from that to which he had taken us, came, and took us again on board his boat— About three hours later than he had engaged— About 10 O’Clock we reached the wharf at New-York.— I went immediately to all the wharves where the Packets for New-Haven, New-London, Newport and Providence lay, and found one of them going this afternoon to New-London— Of those for Providence, the packet by that name is the first to go, and expects to sail on Saturday— I then went to the City-Hotel, and afterwards to Coll: Smith’s; where I proposed to my sister that she should with her son and daughter go on with me, which she concluded to do— As she could not be prepared to go before Saturday, I determined to take passage in the Packet for Providence— I dined and spent the Evening at Coll: Smith’s— Call’d at Mr: King’s and at Mr: M’Cormick’s, but neither of them was at home. I lodged at the City-Hotel— I found Mr: Talmadge, Mr: Mosely, Mr: Pitken and Mr: Nelson there— They came from Philadelphia by the same route that we had taken; they arrived at South-Amboy yesterday, after we cross’d the ferry— The Boat from New-York arrived there about the same time, and they prevailed upon the owners to return immediately; so that they arrived here last Evening.

13. I called at Mr: King’s this forenoon and spent an hour with him, and again in the Evening— Dined at Coll: Smith’s. Engaged a passage for Mrs: Smith, her children and myself in the Providence Packet, Captain Curry; which is to sail to-morrow, if the wind and weather should permit— But it snow’d the whole of this day and Evening with the wind at North-East.

14. The Storm abated this morning, but the wind continued Easterly, untill it was too late to accomplish the passage through Hell-Gate, and the Packet could not sail— I dined with Mr: Hastings at Mr: King’s; and spent the Evening also there— I call’d again at Mr: M’Cormick’s; but did not find him at home— Mr: Elliot was here from Washington; and Mr: Fessenden call’d to pay me a visit.

15. At 9 O’Clock this morning I embarked with my Sister Smith, her son John and her daughter Caroline on board the Providence Packet, and soon after sailed from the wharf— We have fifteen or sixteen fellow passengers; among whom are Mr: Nelson—Mr: Otis, who arrived from Washington last Evening; and Mr: William Clarke, a very old acquaintance of mine; but whom I have seen but little, the last ten or twelve years— We sailed with a fair but very light breeze; pass’d Hell-Gate about eleven O’Clock, and during the remainder of the day and Evening had almost a total calm.

16. The wind was very small, through the Night, and during great part of it entirely calm. By 9 this morning we were opposite to New-Haven; a light breeze then however sprung up, and continued through the day, barely sufficient to fill the sails— As night came on it freshened a little, and about eleven O’Clock this Night we came to Anchor in Newport harbour— Here we landed three passengers, and the wind having again fallen to a calm, we remained at Anchor during the remainder of the Night.

17. The calm continued the whole Night, and about Sunrise this morning we weighed anchor, and with a very light breeze landed at the wharf in Providence just at noon— Four of our fellow passengers engaged a carriage to take them this Night to Boston— But as I wished with my Sister’s family to go to Quincy, we could not procure a carriage and were obliged to wait for the Stage to-morrow morning— The opposition between the two lines of Stages here, has subsided into a compromise between themselves in consequence of which there is much less accommodation for travellers than heretofore.

18. We found it very difficult this morning to crowd all into the Stage, which was a very old and crazy Carriage— After breaking part of the tackle, and being detained half an hour to repair it before we got out of Providence, we cross’d the Sea-Conk river, in a flat-bottom’d boat, at the place where the middle bridge was, of the three which were lately swept away by the floods and Ice—we came in to the Turnpike road about seven miles on this side of the river— All our trunks lashed behind the Carriage were twice lost from it by the unskillfulness of the driver, and the second time the latch of the lock upon my trunk was broken, and all the contents of the trunk, books and clothing were thrown out into the mud, in the middle of the road— The trunk was still held to the carriage by the rope fastened to one of its handles, and dragg’d upwards of a mile along the road before we discovered the accident— By the length of time lost, in recovering the trunks, and my clothes & books, we were so detained that it was 4. in the afternoon before we reached the house at Wrentham where we dined— Here however we obtained a better Carriage— At Dedham we attempted, but without success to procure a carriage for my Sister and her children to go to Quincy— About 9. O’Clock at Night we arrived in Boston; and went first to Whitcomb’s at Concert-Hall; where I quite unexpectedly found that my wife and family had moved, the day before yesterday, from their lodgings at Mr: Gulliver’s, to my house at the Corner of Nassau-Street and Frog-lane— I went immediately there, and had the pleasure of finding them all well, excepting my youngest child John, who has a severe cold, with some fever— We sent immediately to Whitcomb’s for Mrs: Smith, and her children who soon after came and took their lodgings with us—

19. My Sister, and her family this morning went out to Quincy— I went up into the Town before dinner— But had no leisure for attention to any thing afterwards but to the illness of my child, John, whose fever was so high that we sent for Dr: Welsh to visit him.— He left an emetic for him, which produced an effect so violent that we were greatly alarmed, and sent for the Dr: again— He appeared however eventually to be relieved by a discharge of blood, which without knowing its real cause we had apprehended to be more formidable than it really proved.

20. We are still quite unsettled in our dwelling-house, and great part of our furniture is to come from Quincy.— I attended this morning an Auction of books, and made several purchases for the library of Congress— Mr: Shaw called to see us— The child is recovering, but still has much fever— I began to write a little again, but am so much interrupted that I cannot yet return to my regular course of study.

21. Received a load of books and furniture from Quincy, which however was not a fourth part of that which must yet come— J Smith came in from Quincy with a Chaise; and after dinner I went out there with him, and took George with me— I found my father’s family all well excepting my mother who is confined to her chamber

22. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— In the afternoon I went to my own house, and looked over the things there, which are to be sent to us at Boston— I settled with Mr: Briesler the note due from me to him, wishing to finish all my transactions with him as speedily as possible— Returning home I called to enquire first of Mr: W. Baxter, the charge of freighting a lighter to Boston, which he said would be ten dollars; and afterwards at Mr: Cranch’s where I spent part of the Evening— At home I found Captain Beale and his Lady, with my uncle Adams and his Son—my brother gave me an account of his transactions respecting my farm, which is disposed of much better than it stands at present, and would have been better still; but for Briesler

23. This morning I returned with George to Boston in the Stage— And took him to school to a Mrs: Parker’s, whose house is immediately opposite our own— John is yet not well enough to go out— I spent part of the Evening at Mr: W. Smith’s. Caroline was at Dr: Welsh’s— I employed as much of the day in writing as I could secure; which was not much.

24. I still write by quarters of an hour as I can catch them. Young Faxon came in this morning from Quincy with a few more articles of our furniture— I called this afternoon at Mr: Shaw’s Office, where I met Mr: B. Welles & Mr W. H. Sumner. I went to Cambridge; and agreed with President Webber to attend on Friday.

25. Caroline Johnson went out to Quincy last Evening with Mr: Black, on a visit to Mr: T. Greenleaf’s; and to attend a Ball this Evening at Quincy.— Mr: I. P. Davis met me this day in the Street, and proposed to me to purchase two of his dwelling-houses in this town. I came to no conclusion with him, but am to take the subject into consideration— I took George this afternoon a walk in the Mall, and upon Beacon-Hill.

26. Caroline returned from Quincy this morning with Mr: T. Greenleaf— I went with Mr: I. P. Davis, and looked over the house which he has for sale in Hancock Street; but came to no final agreement with him respecting the purchase— Mr: Shaw dined with us— Miss Dexter call’d to see Mrs: Adams and Caroline— Towards Evening, I walk’d with George again in the Mall—

Health and Illness

div.p: 27. I walk’d to Cambridge this morning, and as I had agreed with the President went first to the Library; but found that was not open— I then called at Dr: Waterhouse’s; and at 10. O’Clock, read my twelfth lecture— There was during the same time, a meeting of the Government of the College, to punish some excesses which have happened within a few days— After the Lecture, as the library was shut, and I had no special occupation untill dinner time, it being good-Friday, I went to Church, where I heard prayers read, and a Sermon from Isaiah 53.3. (I presume Sherlock’s) read by Mr: Sewall— After Church I called at Mr: Greenleaf’s— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and at 2. attended the declamations— There were only four of the ten, that spoke— The whole College were much out of humour, at the punishments which have been inflicted— I returned to Boston in the Stage,—with Snow, which fell slightly, several hours— The morning and Evening however were perfectly clear— I spent the Evening at home, and just after going to bed was roused by the illness of Mrs: Adams who had a fainting fit— I was also much offended at the proceedings of a man Servant, who after being out untill near midnight came home much intoxicated, and finding the doors fast, entered by the cellar; where I found him. The good I hope to derive from this accident is a due degree of vigilance respecting the closing of the house; to which I have hitherto been too remiss.

28. My father came in this morning from Quincy, with my Sister and her daughter, and Son— I dined with my father, and the visitors of the professorship of Natural History at Mr: Emerson’s— Evening at home— Mrs: Adams rode out this morning; with Caroline, and John— She was afterwards very well, untill after supper, and then had a very sudden fainting fit again— The cares and anxieties arising from the illness of my wife and child, with the domestic affairs which harrass me have yet left me no time for writing; and this day I was in a great degree disqualified by an almost total loss of rest last Night, for doing any thing—

29. This being Easter-Sunday, I took George with me in the morning and heard Mr: Gardiner at Trinity-Church, and in the afternoon Mr: Freeman, at the stone Chapel— Their discourses were both occasional, and both very pleasing to me. I spent the Evening at home with Mrs: Adams, who is yet very unwell— I read the first two Sermons in the 5th: volume of Tillotson—Both of which are controversial Treatises against the doctrines of the Romish Church.

30. I attended an Auction of furniture, but found nothing to suit me— Called afterwards at Mr: Shaw’s Office— Excepting a walk in the Mall towards Evening I pass’d the remainder of the day and Evening at home— Having little or no rest in the Night I am incapable of application in the day-time— Mrs: Adams is yet ill; and has this day a severe cough— I read however something in Vossius, and began Claude on the composition of a Sermon— I also began to write the first sketch of my eighteenth Lecture.

31. This Morning before breakfast I went out to D. Baxter’s wharf in my neighbourhood; and after breakfast went to market. A violent Snow-Storm commenced early this morning, and continued through the day— It had been preceded by a remarkable appearance proceeding from the Sun which I observed just before Sun-set last Evening— It rendered part of my house uninhabitable, by the smoking of the Chimney’s— The Severity of the Season resembles the middle of January, far more than the last of March— Mrs: Adams is now so ill with a cough that she was confined this day to her chamber. Our youngest child is not yet entirely recovered.

Day— Since my return I have not yet been able to attain any regularity in my course of life— The inconveniences of my house, and of a removal, with the illness of my wife and child have only left me to hope for something better.
